docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-9 Crackdown on bin Laden Leads to Arrests in Europe More than a dozen Islamic militants have been arrested in Germany and Britain, and American officials say some were plotting terror attacks in Europe and elsewhere. The arrests are part of a crackdown on a network with ties to Osama bin Laden, the Saudi radical accused of plotting the bombing of two American embassies in Africa in 1998. A1 Jamal Ahmed Al-Fadl, once an aide to Mr. bin Laden, testified in New York City that he had offered Saudi officials a plan to assassinate Mr. bin Laden, and later discussed it with American officials. He did not disclose the American response. B3

docs.lead_paragraph: One of Archbishop Edward M. Egan's first acts as a newly named cardinal in New York City will be to lead a political offensive in Albany to thwart a bill that would require Catholic hospitals and schools to provide insurance coverage for contraceptives for their female employees. Though previous cardinals have used their influence to shape events in the capital, Archbishop Egan's vow to come to Albany and wade into a public debate on the bill seems to signal that he intends to use his office as a bully pulpit, rather than work behind the scenes.

headline.main: Egan to Head to Albany to Fight Coverage of Contraceptives in Women's Health Bill

docs.abstract: Archbishop Edward M Egan says he will travel to Albany to lead drive against women's health bill approved by New York State Assembly that would require health insurers to cover contraceptives; Catholic Church holds bill would force religious schools and hospitals to cover female employees in violation of their moral tenets; Egan will meet with Gov George E Pataki and legislative leaders; Senate-approved bill exempts religious institutions; conference committee has been unable to reach compromise (M)
docs.snippet: One of Archbishop Edward M. Egan's first acts as a newly named cardinal in New York City will be to lead a political offensive in Albany to thwart a bill that would require Catholic hospitals and schools to provide insurance coverage for...

docs.lead_paragraph: On a Sunday afternoon last October, Ingeborg Coffman was working in the photo lab of the Wal-Mart store in Plant City, Fla., when two fellow technicians asked her to look at a disturbing print that one of them had developed. It showed a boy of maybe 8 or 10 sitting on what looked like a toilet, Ms. Coffman recalled, his arms and legs bound together with silver duct tape. The boy ''was in misery'' and appeared to be crying, and an adult could be seen nearby, she said in an interview last week. She suspected child abuse.

headline.main: A Tempest Over Photo of Shackled Boy

docs.abstract: Ingeborg Coffman of Plant City, Fla, has filed wrongful-dismissal suit against Wal-Mart Stores, which contends that it only reprimanded her for failing to follow company policy; Coffman was dismissed for giving police copy of photo she discovered at store's photo lab showing young boy shackled to toilet, which Coffman saw as act of child abuse, although photo turned out to be prank; Coffman gave copy of photo to police; photo (M) requested photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: As Congress debates whether Medicare should be expanded to cover all prescription drugs, prosecutors have laid out evidence in court of how one drug company used the federal health care program and private insurers to make indirect payments to doctors who prescribed its drug. Prosecutors in the United States attorney's office in Boston have charged a urologist with conspiring with a drug maker, identified in court filings as Company X, to receive excessive payments from Medicare, which investigators said were indirect kickbacks and bribes for writing prescriptions for Lupron, a drug used to treat prostate cancer.

headline.main: Court Papers Depict Scheme In Drug Billing

docs.abstract: Federal prosecutors reportedly negotiate settlement with TAP Pharmaceutical Products of charges TAP illegally used Medicare system to help hundreds of doctors profit from prescribing Lupron, prostate cancer drug; details of company's alleged scheme to use federal health care program and private insurers to make indirect payments to doctors who prescribe drug are outlined in court documents filed against urologist Dr Joseph Spinella; scheme has helped spawn black market for drug (M)
docs.snippet: As Congress debates whether Medicare should be expanded to cover all prescription drugs, prosecutors have laid out evidence in court of how one drug company used the federal health care program and private insurers to make indirect payments to...

docs.lead_paragraph: HOW I CAME INTO MY INHERITANCE And Other True Stories By Dorothy Gallagher 187 pages. Random House. $22.95. BALD IN THE LAND OF BIG HAIR A True Story By Joni Rodgers 253 pages. HarperCollins. $24. Cancer and communism may not be laughing matters, but they're funnier than you'd think in two new memoirs by unusually candid and gutsy women. Joni Rodgers, who was diagnosed with non-Hodgkin's lymphoma and writes frankly about her experiences in ''Bald in the Land of Big Hair,'' tries to find a joke at every possible turn, as in: ''Why didn't the home health nurse cross the road? Because the chicken's H.M.O. wouldn't approve it!''

headline.main: Facing Chemo or Pinkos, and Still Smilin'

docs.abstract: Janet Maslin reviews Bald in the Land of Big Hair: A True Story by Joni Rodgers; reviews How I Came Into My Inheritance: And Other True Stories by Dorothy Gallagher; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, strapped for cash and desperate to find new income, has begun charging a universal fee for prescription drugs at the pharmacies of all its public hospitals and community clinics. Under the new policy, which was quietly introduced last month, patients are charged a $10 ''processing fee'' for each prescription filled, with a cap of $40. There are also some exemptions.

headline.main: City Hospitals Imposing Fees At Pharmacies

docs.abstract: New York City Health and Hospitals Corp begins charging processing fee for prescription drugs at pharmacies of its public hospitals and community clinics; critics say poor and uninsured will be discouraged from getting drugs they need and end up in emergency rooms as untreated conditions become more serious; with corporation facing $317 million deficit, Dr Luis R Marcos, president, says fee is necessary; some patients are exempt from fee, and no one is to be turned away because of finances, although some patients claim that is indeed happening (M)
docs.snippet: The city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, strapped for cash and desperate to find new income, has begun charging a universal fee for prescription drugs at the pharmacies of all its public hospitals and community clinics.    Under the new policy,...

docs.lead_paragraph: Vivian Cabey stood on the stone porch of 60 West 129th Street, collecting her breath and her children after a bruising day at work. On this fall night, darkness had reached the block before she had, and ominous shadows played around her. Like Stygian guides, young men flitted in and out of the building with crackheads in tow. Mrs. Cabey barked that she would beat them or call the police. They kowtowed -- ''You know we respect you more than anyone on the block, Mrs. Cabey'' -- but the traffic continued.
docs.abstract: Second article in series An American Block: Life on 129th Street focuses on residents whose lives still seem hardly improved by revival of once devastated block; block has long been poorer and more populous than brownstone-lined blocks around it and residents affected by generations of straitened circumstances; graphs; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: REMEMBER the Reagan years? Republicans couldn't stop predicting they were on the verge of becoming the new majority party. They were wrong, it turned out, and although the Republicans now control the White House, House and Senate for the first time since the Eisenhower administration, no one in the party has yet declared victory over the Democrats.

headline.main: The Nation; High-Stakes Politics: The Race to Rule the Nation

docs.abstract: Comment on Republican and Democratic efforts to fashion their political agendas, with balance of power in Congress so even; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Vickie L. Milazzo was growing up in one side of a shotgun house in New Orleans, her parents could not fathom the unbroken hours she spent teaching an imaginary class of students. ''My father would tell the class to take a break and I'd say, 'No, no, come back,' '' she said. It was good training for the six-day, eight-hour seminars that she teaches today. But now her students are real: legions of nurses are paying Ms. Milazzo to instruct them on how to become legal nurse consultants.
docs.abstract: Profile of Vickie L Milazzo, a nurse who went on to become a lawyer and then founder of Medical-Legal Consulting Institute, which offers intensive seminars for nurses on how to become legal nurse consultants; nurse consultants are in great demand to help lawyers interpret all medical issues; photo (M)
